awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaporation-Driven Optofluidic Biosensors using Photonic Crystal Biosilica
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research project is to explore sensing of biological substances using naturally occurring diatoms, which are a group of single-celled algae found in nature that have been shown to possess unique properties suitable for biosensing applications.   This research could lead to new methods to detect many types of biomolecules, which would in turn positively impact pollution monitoring, hazardous material detection, and early disease diagnosis.  The integration of this research with education and outreach efforts benefits both graduate and undergraduate students at Oregon State University and Washington State University-Vancouver.  Programmatic topics on nanophotonic technology and microfluidics are being added to curricula of these institutions, and efforts are underway to try to broaden the participation of under-represented minorities, women and K-12 students at these institutions through the summer research programs. 

Evaporation-induced capillary flow in micro- and nano-scale structures can sustain a liquid flow without external pumps, and this can be a desirable feature for biosensing. The goal of this research project is to develop a new type of evaporation-driven, optofluidic biosensor using diatom photonic crystal biosilica. Diatoms are a group of single-celled photosynthetic algae that use biochemical pathways to biomineralize and self-assembled three-dimensional photonic crystals with unique photonic and micro- and nano-fluidic properties. Three aims are being pursued: 1) investigation of evaporation-induced capillary forces in the arrayed micro- and nanopores of diatom biosilica; 2) development of an optofluidic biosensor with enhanced light-matter interactions through in-pore plasmonic nanoparticles and 3) enabling a lab-on-chip optofluidic sensing system for trace level of biomarker detection, specifically for histamine as allergy biomarkers, using surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensing.  This research could lead to label-free sensing of many small biomolecules, which would positively impact pollution monitoring, hazardous material detection, and early disease diagnosis. The synergy of the research and education parts of this project benefits both graduate and undergraduate students at Oregon State University and Washington State University-Vancouver by enhancing their curricula with nanophotonic technology and microfluidics topics. The research project also has a component of broadening the participation of under-represented minorities, women and K-12 students through summer research programs.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
We have successfully fabricated a simple yet effective self-powered evaporation-driven optofluidic bisosensor which consists of a sample reservoir, microfluidic channel, and diatom basilica film. The diatom thin film simultaneously serves dual purposes: optical sensing and passive pumping (porous evaporator). Our diatom-based microfluidic device is fabricated with the microfabrication technology, which makes the device compact size, highly portable, low cost, and easy to use in bio-molecule detection. The micro Particle Image Velocimetry (?PIV) method was used to measure the flowrate of our device under different operating conditions (e.g., the size of diatom film, temperature). We have demonstrated the capability of the fabricated microfluidics to produce steady and continuous flow over 48 hours due to the superhydrophilic nature of diatom biosilica film. We also showed that the flow rate can be controlled by adjusting the biosilica film area and heating temperature. It was found that temperature of the diatom film had the greatest impact on flow rate for the tested range of substrate areas. The evaporation rates predicted from the boundary layer model were in good agreement with the experimental measurements, signifying that the proposed theoretical model can be used for design of evaporation-driven microfluidic devices. Through the project, we discovered fundamental relationships between flow rate, fluid properties, fluidics design, and flow conditions, which helped us optimize the design of the evaporation-driven pumping system. This research also advanced the knowledge of microscopic transport phenomena in complex nanoporous diatom film. Our work promoted the research of optofluidics with unprecedented capabilities and high reliability for biosensing and fluidic control.

Additionally, we have developed a high-speed imaging system for visualization of fluid flow at micrometer scale. Our whole setup comprises the mounting platform, light source, inkjet system, CCD camera, magnification lens, and pulse generator. With the help of developed high-speed imaging system, we have studied the interfacial fluid dynamics associated with the droplet impact on micropatterned hydrophilic surfaces and microholed surfaces. For the first time, we discovered that a rapid tiny jet could emerge during the droplet impact on a hydrophilic surface instead of superhydrophobic surface. We also showed that drople impact over a microhole on the thin plate can precisely eject a single microdroplet, which can be used as a novel Drop-on-Demand printing method.Our work advanced understanding of inertial focusing flow induced jetting and microdroplet ejecting phenomena.

The project has trained four graduate students and three undergraduate students. Seven journal papers and two conference papers have been pulished to report our findings to the research commnutiy of microfluidics and interfacial dynamics. Three graduate students completed their master thesis research with the support from the project.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2022
Modified by: Hua Tan
